"&YOGH;e, al. A &yogh;e sire," quath þe widewe : "god &yogh;elde þe þin ore!" Þe widewe nam hom hire best : and ne &yogh;eld it him nammore. Þis Auntur bi-fel ofte siþe : &yogh;wane men him wolden bidde ou&yogh;t; heriot of pouere men : he ne wilnede ri&yogh;ht nou&yogh;ht.— ¶ We ne mowen rikeni nou&yogh;t al. nowhar ne&yogh; : alle is guode dedes. For euere in strong penaunce i-nou&yogh; : is lif he gan lede, And treuliche heold up holi churche : and wuste hire fram ech wou&yogh;. Þare-fore hadde þe deuel of helle : to him onde i-nou&yogh; : he bi-gan for-to a-rere contek : bi-tweone him a-non And þe king hanri þat was þo : þe kingues sone Ioan. Þe king and muche del of is folk : a-&yogh;ein holie churche was, Ase king henri, is graunt-sire : hadde a-&yogh;ein seint Thomas; And þat couent of caunturburi al-so : a-&yogh;ein him hul[d] wel faste; Ofte huy nomen louedai : ake þet contek euere i-laste. ¶ A legat was þo in engelonde : þat a-&yogh;ein him was al-so. Ake studefast was euere þis holie man : þei he luyte help hadde þar-to. huy ne mi&yogh;ten a-cordi for no-þing : ake þe lengore þe worse it was; Ake euere nam þis holie man : ensaumple of seint thomas. Wel ofte he bad þe kingue and his : &yogh;if it were heore wille, Þat huy ne weorreden nou&yogh;t a-&yogh;ein holi churche al. H. ch. to werri no&yogh;t : ake laten hire beo stille In hire fraunchise and in pays : ase heo hadde i-beo &yogh;are. Þe king þretnede þene holie man : bote he bi-lefde is fare. ¶ "Of þi þretningue ich telle luyte" : seide þis holie man, "For &yogh;if þou me drifst out of þi lond : an oþur red ich can : Ich can rede at parys : ase ich are þis habbe i-do, And þare-with winne me mete i-nov&yogh; : and cloþingue al-so. &YOGH;if þou me dest to deþe bringue : þou paist me wel i-nov&yogh;; Þou ne mi&yogh;htest don me non more honour : þane slen me þoru&yogh; þi wou&yogh;." ¶ &YOGH;uyt eft, ase he ofte dude : to þe king he sende; And he answerede þe leng þe wors : and no-þing nolde a-mende. Þo þis holie man i-sai&yogh;h : þat non-oþur it nolde beo, Þoru&yogh;h holi churche he gan to fi&yogh;hte : and a-corsede alle þeo Þat weorreden a-&yogh;ein al. om. þe churche of caunturburi : and with on-ri&yogh;hte duden schame; And some þat he gulti wuste : he a-mansede bi name. ¶ To þe king and to is conseil : þis word wel sone drou&yogh;. Ne þarf no man esche : weþur huy weren wroþe i-nov&yogh;! Þare was þretningue and bost i-nov&yogh;. : seint Eadmund heold him stille, And stifliche heold forth þe sentence : and liet heom speke heore wille. Seint Thomas cam and spak with him : and gostliche fram heouene a-li&yogh;hte, And bad him beo stif and studefast : to holde up þe churches ri&yogh;hte, And for non eorþelich anuy : ne for deþe, ne flechchie nou&yogh;ht, Ake nime ansaumple of him and oþure : þat so deore as hadde a-bou&yogh;t. ¶ Seint Eadmund feol a-doun a-kneo : and is hondene heold up al-so To cusse þis holie mannes fiet. : ake he ne moste it nou&yogh;ht do. Þo bi-gan he to weope sore i-nov&yogh; : and seide "louerd, þin ore!" "beo stille," quath seint Thomas to him : "and ne weop þou so non|more! &YOGH;wi wilnestþou to cusse mine fiet? : it nere þe no ri&yogh;ht to do, Þou schalt newene þine wille habbe : and cusse mine mouth al-so." ¶ Seint Eadmund aftur þulke tyme : studefast was i-nov&yogh;, To dei&yogh;e raþur for holie churche : þane men duden hire any wov&yogh;. he þou&yogh;hte muche on seint Thomas : þat out of londe wende Þe &yogh;wyle þe kyng was in mest wrathþe : &yogh;if he wolde ou&yogh;t amende: Of him he nam ensaumple : and priueliche i-nov&yogh; he wende out of Enguelonde : and into Fraunce he drou&yogh;. And þou&yogh;hte he was at pounteneye : swiþe faire under-fongue And isusteyned in his anuy : þat i-laste longue; ¶ Also steuene of languetone : þat Erchebischop was, Six &yogh;er he was at pounteneye : in þat sulue cas. Þo al. so þat seint Eadmund under-stod : of is Auncetres i-nowe, &YOGH;wane huy weren in contek for holie churche : to pounteneye heom drowe: Also dude seint Eadmund— : to pounteneye he wende, For-to a-bide þe stat of holie churche : &yogh;wane ore louerd it wolde amende. honoured he was faire i-nov : of alle þat þare were, And euere a-bod a-mendement : fram &yogh;ere to &yogh;ere. langor. ¶ Hit bi-fel, ase god wolde : þat seint Eadmund atþe laste Fielde is bodi heui i-nov&yogh; : and fieblede swiþe faste; So longue, þat he was so feble : þat men ne radde him nou&yogh;ht beo þere, Ake for-to soiorni elles-&yogh;ware : þare betere eir to him were. Þis holie man is leue nam : elles-&yogh;wodere to wiende; Þe Monekes mauden so muche deol : þat þar-of nas non ende. ¶ "beth stille," quat þis holie man : "for ichulle þoru alle þing Comen hidere a&yogh;ein to eou : a-seint Eadmundes day þe kyng." Louerd, in swuche siknesse : wuch a word þat was i-seid! Ake, &yogh;wane he ne mi&yogh;hte bi is liue : forewar[d] he heold heom ded! Forth he wende with is men : þudere ase guod eir were: To þe toun of Soysi : and bi-lefde þere. ¶ So longue so it was, þare he eode : in grete siknesse i-nov&yogh;, So longue þat he lay a-doun : and toward þe deþe drov&yogh;. So þat he Axede ore louerdes flechs : and it was him i-brou&yogh;ht. he sat and bi-heold it faste i-nou&yogh; : in gret studie and in þou&yogh;ht, Longue are he seide ani word : and þo spak he wel inliche: "louerd," he seide, "þou it art : þat ich habbe i-loued treweliche, ¶ And treweliche on þe ich [habbe] bi-leue[d] al. bileued, ich habbe om. : and i-preched of þe al-so, And þou treweliche at min ende-day : art i-come me to. Ich take þe, louerd, to witnesse : þe &yogh;wyle ich habbe on vrþe i-beo, Þat i-ne wilnede neuere aftur al. om. no-þing on vrþe : louerd, so muche ase aftur al. om. þe." A,. louerd, þat it al. þis was an hei&yogh;h word : and he þat so sede Guod and holi moste he be : and swiþe holi lif lede! Þo he hadde i-nome ore louerdes flechs : he sat longue in þou&yogh;hte, And al lei&yogh;hinde on Englichs : þeos wordes forth he brou&yogh;hte: "Men seggez þat game goth in wombe : ake i segge game goth in heorte." A v. om.? Of ore louerd þat he hadde i-nome : wel Ioyful he was þo, And al is game was in is heorte— : for is bodi was ful of wo. Þe more is bodi i-pined was : þe ner he was þen ende; And þo is ende-day was i-come : he wuste &yogh;wodere wiende. ¶ Euere þe more þat he was : in sicknesse and in wo, Þe gladdore he was, for he wuste : &yogh;wodere he scholde go, And þe more he was al. lo&yogh; in Ioye : and þe muregore him gan like. Men nuste him nou&yogh;ht enes ligge a-doun : to groni ne to siche, Ake euere he sat glad i-nou&yogh; : and lenede al-so wel ofte Opon cloþes oþur opon is hond : and deide faire and softe. Fair semblaunt he maude i-nov&yogh; : ase he drov to þen ende; In þe moreweningue ase þe sonne a-ros : out of þis world he gan wiende. ¶ He deide twelf hundred &yogh;er : and to and-fourti ri&yogh;ht Aftur þat ore swete louerd : in is moder was a-li&yogh;ht. Men leten openi him a-non : & is gottus take And burie heom þare ase he was ded : in þe Munstre of seint Iake; Men nomen is holie bodi : and wel faire gunne it lede To þe Abbeye of pounteneye : ase he him-sulf er sede. A-seint Eadmundus dai þe king : þudere he was i-brou&yogh;ht— he heold þe Monekes foreward : and ne failede heom nou&yogh;ht: ¶ For þo he ne cam nou&yogh;ht a-liue a&yogh;ein : ded he dude, i-wis! And þare he was i-brou&yogh;ht on vrþe : and i-schrined al-so he is; he lith þare faire i-nov&yogh; : and with gret honour al-so. Mani is þe faire Miracle : þat god hath for him i-do. Nou god for þe loue of him : and þat us deore bou&yogh;hte, To þulke blisse us bringue : þat he is soule brou&yogh;hte. AmeN

54.1: SEint Martyn was i-bore : in þe londe of sabarie; Wel &yogh;ong he was i-noriced : in þe londe of papie. A noble kny&yogh;ht is fadur was : and Maister of þe fierde, Vnder Costantyn þe Aumperour : and al is .Ost. he stierde. For al. om., r. forth? into batayle he brou&yogh;hte is &yogh;oungue sone : þar-of him to lere. None heorte nadde he þer-to : for huy heþene were; his heorte bar him euere to Iesu crist : þei he i-cristned nere, he i-sai&yogh;h þat heore bi-leue nas nau&yogh;ht : þat huy bi-lefden þere. ¶ To churche, þo he was Twelf &yogh;er old : stilleliche he wende And bi-hiet ore louerd cristine to beo : &yogh;wane he þe time him sende. ¶ Þe Aumperour het MS. h i et? into al þat lond : to euereche olde kni&yogh;te Þat heore sones scholden into batayle comen : and for heore faderes fi&yogh;hte. So þat þe &yogh;ungue seint Martin : nas bote of fiftene &yogh;er Þo he [þe armes] om. in eche bataile : for is fadere ber. A winter ase þis child rod : bi þe weye al one, A Miseise man he mette naked : sore sike and grone. Seint Martyn drov&yogh; out is swerd : ase we findeth in þe bok, MS. boke And carf is Mantel half a-to : and þe pouere Manne it bi-tok. ¶ Sone aftur-ward, ase he bi-heold : to-ward heouene an hei&yogh;h, with is halue Mantel i-heled : ore louerd crist he sei&yogh;h: "lo," he seide to is Aungles : "þis ne worth me nou&yogh;ht bi-reued; Martin, þat is heþene &yogh;uyt : here-with me hath bi-weued." Þo Martin þis i-herde : and ore louerd he sai&yogh;h þere, Glad ne bliþe nolde he beo : are he i-cristned were. ¶ Ei&yogh;htetene &yogh;er he was old : þo he i-cristned was; Þat he hadde so longue a-bide : ofte he seide alas. Ake al þe to &yogh;er þare-afturward : in-to batailes he wende For is fader wide a-boute : ase þe Aumperor him sende. hit bi-fel of a gret bataile : þat þe Aumperor hadde i-nome, he het alle is kny&yogh;htes in is lond : þat huy scholden to him come; he het orig. hiet Martyn with heom wende : and Armure with him take. "Certes, sire," Martin seide, "þine Armes ich habbe for-sake, ¶ Ich am Iesu cristes kny&yogh;ht : and so ich habbe i-beo longue, And none oþure Armes bote his : i-nelle vnder-fongue." "Ei, couward," seide þe Aumperour : "nouþe þou sparest for fere For-to fi&yogh;hte with þine felawes : ase þi ri&yogh;te were?" "Sire," seide Martin þo : "þe soþe þou schalt i-se, Of þine Armes ne kepe i nou&yogh;ht : ake þe furste ichulle beo Al one bi-fore al þi folk : naked to þe bataile; Mine louerdes mi&yogh;hte þou schalt i-seo : for he me nele nou&yogh;t faile." ¶ Þo þat ferd al-&yogh;are was : seint Martin wende a-non Vn-armed with is swerd a-drawe : among alle is fon. Þo he a-mong hem was i-come : þare nas of hem nou&yogh;ht on Þat mi&yogh;hte ani more hebbe up is hond : þane it were a ston; huy &yogh;olden him þe maistrie a-non : bote þat he let hem a-liue. Seint Martin clepede is felawes : and het hem hom wel bliue. "Sire Aumperour," he seide, "nouþe þou sixt : &yogh;wuch is mi louerdes mi&yogh;hte; Are &yogh;e alle it hadden þar-to i-brou&yogh;ht : longue &yogh;e mosten fi&yogh;hte! ¶ Nov þou hast alle þine fon i-wonne : þonke god, and nou&yogh;ht me, And haue guod day, for i-nelle : no lengore serui þe." he nam is leue and wende forth : —he nolde no leng a-bide— To þe holie bischop hyllari : þat wonede þare-bi-side. Of him he was i-maud a-colite : and dude al bi is rede. Ore louerd cam to him a ni&yogh;ht : and þeos wordes to him seide : ¶ "Ich hote þe, Martin, þat þou go : wel ofte to þine kunne, And spec with hem, &yogh;if þov mi&yogh;ht : bringue hem out of sunne; Þei þat huy heþene beon : ne let heom nou&yogh;ht þare-fore, For ech guod man schal Anouri þat kun : þat he was of i-bore. Ake gret a-nuy þov schalt habbe : þe &yogh;wile þou gest a-boute; Þe &yogh;wyle þou mine grace hast : þe þarf no-wi&yogh;ht doute." Þis guode Man, ase ore louerd him het : to-ward is kun wende. orig. hiet Strongue outlawes bi þe wei he mette : heore bouwes sone huy bende, Þis guode man huy nomen : and maden him mani a wounde, Forth huy ladden him for-to sle : is hondene faste i-bounde. Þe outlawes axede him &yogh;if he were : so sore a-drad euere. "Nai, certes," quath þis holie man : "þat al. so siker nas ich neuere. ¶ Ore louerdes hel p was euere nei&yogh;h : þe manne þat was in care : So muche is þar-to min hope : þat i-ne rechche hou ich fare." Of Ihesu crist he tolde so : with heom þat him nome, Þat huy ful sone leten him go : and cristine for him bi-come. Ase þis guode Man eode forth al one : þe deuel a-&yogh;ein him cam; In faire manere he axede him : &yogh;wodere þene wei he nam. Þis guode Man seide, "ichulle go : ase mi louerd wole lede me." "&YOGH;wodere þou go," þe oþur seide : "þe deuel wole a&yogh;ein þe beo." ¶ "&YOGH;e," seide þis guode Man : "þou most wel al-so; For &yogh;wane ore louerd is min help : i-ne rechche &yogh;wat oþure do." Þis guode Man eode a-mong is freond : is moder cristine he made; his fader nolde cristine be : for al þat huy him bede.— Seint Martin fond a &yogh;ong man ded : þat swiþe wel with him was, Þat bi-lefde on ore louerd for him : ake i-cristned nou&yogh;t he nas. ¶ Gret deol made þis holie man : þat he nadde ibe i-cristned er : To is burieles he eode, and bad for him : and weop wel mani a ter. Þe dede Man bi-gan a-non : fram deþe arise to liue; "Martin," he seide, "i-hered beo þou : and ore louerdes woundes fiue! Mi soule was to helle i-lad : ase alle beoth of oure kuynde, Ake tweye Aungles þoru&yogh; godes grace : hadden me in muynde And seiden ore louerd þat ich hadde : ouwer desciple i-beo; Þare-fore ore louerd me dude a-rise : for þe honour of þe And dude mi soule to mi bodi : for þi loue hider bringue. Cristine-dom par charite : ich esche bi-fore alle þingue." ¶ Gret Ioye hadde þis holie Man : of þis swete cas; he nolde departi fram him nou&yogh;ht : are he i-cristned was.— Þat folk nam sethþe seint Martin : for he was so guod, And maden him bischop of turoyne : muche a-&yogh;ein is mod. To mile with-oute þe cite : an Abbeye he liet a-rere; Four-score Monekes of guode liue : him-sulf he dude þere. with heom he wonede al in pays : ase he heore soueren were; he ne wende nou&yogh;ht out bote &yogh;wane it neod was : þat folk for-to lere.— ¶ So holi lif seint Martin ladde : þat he hadde to is heste Fuyr., and treo., and þe kuynde of worm : of foules and of beste. a v. om. A strong wind blev&yogh; a fuyr : þat to seint Martines house it wende, And are þis guode man it onder-&yogh;ete : i-barnd was þat on ende. Seint Martyn hiet a-godes name : þat fuyr a-&yogh;ein wiende : For is heste þat fuyr flev&yogh; : a-non a-&yogh;ein þe wynde To þe stude þare it cam fram : and ne bi-lefde no-wi&yogh;ht bi-hinde, And dude a-&yogh;ein þe kuynde of fuyre : a-&yogh;ein þe wynde to fle. Þare was i-sene þat fuyr ne mi&yogh;hte : a-&yogh;ein is heste be.— ¶ To is heste he hadde, ase ich seide er : þe kuynde of þe tre, Ase &yogh;e mouwen bi a fair miracle : of him nouþe i-seo. On a dai ase he stod under a treo : to prechi godes lawe, Þe luþere men þat þare-bi stoden : þou&yogh;hten him bringue of dawe : huy gunne sawie þat treo a-to : to-ward þis holie Manne, Þat it scholde ouer-falle him— : for þare nadde he freond nanne. Þoru&yogh; noyse of þe crake&yogh;ingue : þe guode man i-heorde Þat þut treo fel touward him. : a-&yogh;ein wel sone he it cherde; ¶ he het þat treo a-godes name : opward a-&yogh;ein tuyrne. Þat treo a-ros up-ri&yogh;ht i-nou&yogh;h : for it nolde is heste werne, And ouer-ful MS. ouerfalle in þat oþur side : [m]anie MS. anie of is fon. huy þat leoueden, lieten heom sone : cristni euerech-on.— Þe worm dude is heste al-so. : for ase he cam bi a wateres brimme, A lodlich Naddre he i-sai&yogh;h : stifliche a&yogh;ein him come swymme. "Ich hote þe," seide þis holie Man : "þat þov a&yogh;einward wende, A[n]t þat þou neuereft here ne come : ne nou&yogh;were in þis ende." Þis worm turnede a-&yogh;en a-non : ase þis holie Man him het, And swam in-to an oþur lond : and þulke contrei&yogh;e fur-let.— ¶ Foules duden is heste al-so. : for on a time ase he gan gon, he sai&yogh;h douedoppene fisches cachche : and swolewen heom in a-non. "Alas!" seide þis guode man : "þis is þe feondes manere : Gultlese MS. gultlesse þingus and vnwarre : to cachchen, ase huy doth here, And þing þat non harm ne doth : bote wenth in pay[s] to beo; So farez þe deuel, a-waytez euere : for-to he is prei&yogh;e i-seo." he het þe foules a-godes name : ech-one þannes teo And þat huy scholden in-to wildernesse : out of þat watere fleo, Þat huy neueref[t] þare ne comen : gultlese þingues to take. Þis foules a-non with þis word : awei huy gonne schake.— ¶ bestes duden al-so is heste. : for ase he wende a-boute, Aftur ane hare he sai&yogh;h vrne : grehoundes a gret route; "Alas," he seide, "þis seli best : þat no-þing ne doth a-mis! Þis foule houndes it wollez to-drawe : gultles ase it is." he het þe grehoundes a-bide a-non : and ne do þat best no wo; huy at-stunten a-non, and eoden a-&yogh;ein : and lieten þat best forth go. al. 2 vv. more. ¶ On atyme kene houndes comen : a-boute one of is manne; he ne mi&yogh;hte him wite, so kene huy were : ne help nadde he nanne: "Ich hote eov," he seide, "a-godes name : and on seint Martines al-so, Þat &yogh;e me laten a-pais wende : Min erinde for-to do." Þe houndes a-non with þat word : bi-gonne to stonde stille, And wenden euerech in is wey : to do seint Martines wille. ¶ A kov al-so þat was gidi : a-boute orn in þe londe, Þat fale men slov, and bestes al-so : &yogh;ware heo fond anie stonde; hire ne mi&yogh;hte no-þing atstonde a-&yogh;ein : so strong þat foule þing was. A-&yogh;ein seint Martin heo cam eorne : ase ore louerd &yogh;af þat cas; Sore weren is Men a-dradde. : þis guode Man hire het a-non A-godes name stonde stille : and [n]ane MS. ane fot forþere gon. Þat best, þei it gidi were : a-non it gan a-bide. Seint Martin þene deuel i-sai&yogh; : opon hire rugge ride. ¶ "Þov luþere þing &yogh;wat dostþov þer? : for euere þou dost to quede. &YOGH;wy trauailest þou þat selie best : þat ne loueth no misdede? A-corsede þing, þou wend a-wei : ne cum nei&yogh;h hire non-more!" Þe deuel wende a-wei a-non : &yogh;eollinde suyþe sore— he moste nede is heste do : ase wel ase þe kov. Þo heo of him deliured was : ase &yogh;e i-hereth hov, Mildeliche heo eode to seint Martyn : to is fet heo feol a-kneo a-non, And schok hire heued, to þonki him : he nolde fram him gon. ¶ Seint Martin hire het a-risen up : and to ire felawes wende. heo lottede on him and eode forth : hom to ire owene ende.— Seint Martin was apostlene pier : for þe holie gost a-li&yogh;hte In him ase in þe Apostles : in fourme of fuyr wel bri&yogh;hte. A dai ase þis guode Man sat : allone in is celle, his priue Men a-biden him þare-oute : and heorden him loude telle; Al-so ase þei it wummen were : huy heorden with him speke. Þare-of hem þou&yogh;hte wonder gret : ne dorsten huy nou&yogh;t in breke. ¶ Sethþe þo þe guode man cam out : huy fullen a-doun a-kneo, And axeden &yogh;wat þe speche were : þat with him hadde i-beo. Þe guode man seide, "ich may eou telle : for &yogh;e me beoz priue: It was ore lauedi and seint Anneis : þat þare-inne weren with me, Of þe Ioye of heouene huy speken : and ofte huy doth so. Seint petre and seint powel : to me comiez ofte al-so."— Seint Martin at paray place left vacant, paray on the margin; al. paris : mette ane Musel bi cas. he custe him, and anon aftur-ward : þe Musel al hol was.— ¶ Men ne sei&yogh;e him neuere wroth : ne li&yogh;e no-þe-mo, And &yogh;wat-so-euere is Men duden : he wolde euere bi on go. In wel pouere wede a day : he rod out on ane Asse; hei&yogh;e Men he mette bi þe weie : þat tolden of him þe lasse. heore hors weren of him a-drad le : for is pouere cloþes, And ornen a-bach, and felden hem a-doun. : huy weren with him ful wroþe, huy sturten up and nomen þis holie Man : and beoten him ful sore. Euere he was stille and ne spak no word : for þi huy beoten him þe more. ¶ Þo huy him hadden so i-bete : huy bi-lefden [him] atþen ende ligginde þare, and worþen on heore hors : forth heore wei to wende. Ake heore hors nolden gon of þe stude : for al þat huy don al. om. mi&yogh;ten, &YOGH;uyt huy &yogh;uyt huy al. om. smiten with &yogh;eorde and with spore : are þat huy a-li&yogh;hten And criden merci þis guode Man : þat huy him hadden mis-do. heore hors hem bere forth a-non : þo huy token on so.— And in an hous þe &yogh;wile it barnde : he slep wit-oute harm; his cloþes fur-barnden al-to cole : he ne fielde it no-þing warm.— ¶ At a gret feste, ase he scholde : þe hei&yogh;e masse singue, To churche he wende with is men : men gunne a-&yogh;ein him ringue. Ane pouere Man he mette nake : þat no schroud him nadde a-boue, And bad him sum-þing to helien him with : for ore louerdes loue. Seint Martyn bad is Ercedekne : þat he him &yogh;eue sum cloth. Þe Ercedekne tolde þarof luyte : and nolde, he swor is Oth. Seint Martin bote anne Cuyrtel : on him-sulf þo nadde: To þe pouere Manne he hine &yogh;af : in an hous þare he him ladde. ¶ he ne bi-lefde on him no cloth of wolle : bote is Cope al-one. Þe masse ne mi&yogh;hte he bi-guynne nou&yogh;ht : þat folk made þar-of mone. "&YOGH;wy neltþou," seide þe Ercedekne : "þine masse bi-guynne?" "For þou most er ane pouere Manne : sum cloth to him i-winne." "Nov is þis erased? al. hit ," seide þe Ercedekne : "gret a-nuy with þe, For j-ne seo no pouere Man : nou&yogh;were a-boute þe be." "No," seide þis holie man : "it nele faillie þe nou&yogh;ht, Al redi þou findest a pouere Man : habbe þou þat cloth i-b r ou&yogh;th." ¶ Þe Ercedekne in grete wrathþe : eode into chepingue, A lodlich cloth he bou&yogh;hte for fif panes : to þe bischope he gan it bringue. Þe bischop eode into þe vestiarie : is Cope he gan of strepe. he nadde under is vestimenz : to habbe on bote þ is orig. is Iuype, Vnneþe it heolede is derne limes : and nou&yogh;ht folliche is elbouwes; For is bare Armes atþe masse : þis guode man hadde gret houwe— For þe uestimenz wide weren : and is Armes smale and lene; laste is Armes nakede weren i-sei&yogh;e : he ne dorste hebbe op is hond ene. ¶ Ake þo he nedlingus at þe sacrement : is hondene hebbe up scholde, An Aungel schrudde is nakede armes : with tweie sleuene of golde. Harl. 3 vv. more. Þe ercedekne cride and bi-hiet : þat neuere-eft mis-don him he nolde.— Þe deuel hadde to þis holie man : gret onde with-alle. he cam in a time him to bi-traye : in riche cloþus of palle, with hosen and schon of bri&yogh;te golde : swyþe fair he was of face. "Martin," he seide, "wel þe beo : i-founde þou hast mine grace: Ich am þilke þat þou seruest wel : ichulle me schewi to þe; Þov most sone chaungi þi lif : and bi-time come to me." ¶ Þis guode Man sat in gret þou&yogh;ht : no word he ne sede. "Martyn," he seide, "ich am þi freond : &yogh;war-of hastþou drede, &YOGH;wane þin owene god spekez with þe : here mouth with mouþe? Euere þou hast of guode bi-leue i-beo : ne lat it nou&yogh;t faili þe nouþe! For ich blessi alle þat on me bi-leuez : þei huy me nou&yogh;ht ne seo, And er þis þei þov ne sei&yogh;e me nou&yogh;ht : in þulke blessingue þou woldest be." ¶ "I nuste neuere," quath þis guode man : "þat mi louerd euere sede Þat he wolde on vrþe come : in swuche riche kingene wede; And bote ich mouwe of mine louerdes woundes : on þe signe i-se Oþur of is croyz, inelle i-leue : þat þou mi louerd be." Þe foule þing wende a-wey : and was adrad of ane boule; Þe stude þare-Aftur swiþe longue : stonk of him ri&yogh;ht foule. al. 2 vv. more. — ¶ Þis guode Man seide his ende-day : him was swyþe wel come. al. wel longe er hit come his desciples weopen sore : and gret deol to heom nome. "Leoue fader," huy seiden, "&yogh;wat schulle we do : þat þov us wolt for-sake? Vs fader-les with-oute confort : &yogh;wam woltþu bi-take? Nov wollez wilde wolues come : and alle þine schep a-spille." "Ich mot nede," seide þis guode man : "don mine louerdes wille." Of Askene and of is here he made he m. on the margin. : a bed at is ende-day, And þaron feble a&yogh;en is deþe : opri&yogh;ht adoun him-sulue he lay; And toward heouene lokede ay : so longue þat it nas non ende. his Men þou&yogh;hten it dude him harm : and wolden him helpe to wende. ¶ "A-bideth," seide þis holie man : "&yogh;wy wolle &yogh;e don so? latez me ane &yogh;wyle bi-holde þe stude : þat mi soule schal to!" Þo i-sai&yogh;h he þene deuel aftur is soule : stonde þare with is feren. "A-wey," he seide, "þou luþere best : þou nast nou&yogh;t to don here! with me nastþou nou&yogh;t to done : for mi louerd me wole onder fongue; In is name to him ich wende : þat bou&yogh;hte me swiþe strongue." ¶ With þusse worde he &yogh;af þene gost— : Aungles i-redie were, Þat folk heorde heore murie song : ase huy þe soule bere. Four hondret &yogh;er it was : and in þe sixe-and-sixtiþe &yogh;ere Aftur ore louerdes buyrtyme : þat þis guode Man deide þere. Four-score winter he was old : are he was ded al-so. God &yogh;iue us part of þulke ioye : þat is soule wende to.

55.1: SEint leonard þe confessour : a-londe eode her Aftur ore louerdes buyrtyme : a-boute fif hundred &yogh;er. his freond and is cunnes-men : þe gretteste maystres were In þe kyngus house of Fraunce : grettore none þare nere; And seint leonard al-so was : a gret maister with þe king; Of þat he him bidde wolde : he wernde him no-þing. he grauntede him alle þe prisones : þat he fore bidde wolde, Aftur is bone ope al is lond : þat men him al. hem deliueri scholde. ¶ Þis holie man wende a-boute faste : prisones forte glade; And &yogh;wane he fond ani of luyte gult : deliuered sone he made. For-þi Men him cleopeden "prisones louerd" : and &yogh;uyt men doth al-so, For non oþur halewe for prisones : so fair miracle nath i-do.— Þe king of Fraunce him bi-sou&yogh;hte : &yogh;eorne ope al is mi&yogh;hte Þat he scholde with him beo : bi dayes and bi ny&yogh;hte, For-te þare fulle ani bischopriche : þat he him mi&yogh;hte bi-take. Seint leonard nolde it graunti nou&yogh;ht : ake outri&yogh;ht it gan for-sake, And wende forth a-&yogh;ein is wille : and bad him habbe guod day. Formest he wende to Orlians : to prechie godes lay. ¶ Longue he prechede þare-a-boute : þat folk for-to lere; And sethþe he wende to Aquitayne : for-to prechie þere. Eche daye he wolde at toune beo : to prechi godes lawe, And eche ni&yogh;hte he wende to þe wode : &yogh;wane it to eue gan drawe, In is oresones to beon al one— : ac so sone so it was day, In-to þe contreye he wolde a-boute : and prechi godes lay.— ¶ Þe king hadde in þulke wode : a tour of grete bolde, Þat he mi&yogh;hte soiourni þer : &yogh;wane he euere wolde. Þe Quene was with childe grete : þudere men gonne hire bringue, &YOGH;if heo þe betere mi&yogh;hte for solas : ouer-come hire childingue. Þo he was in trauail : heo ne mi&yogh;hte ouer-come it nou&yogh;ht; So sore heo pinede þat heo was : wel nei&yogh;h to deþe i-brou&yogh;ht. ¶ Þe king, and alle his, gret deol maden : þat crie men heorde hem wide; And þo seint leonard herde þar-of : he gan heorkni and a-bide. Þo he i-heorde þat it was of men : þudere he gan wende, &YOGH;if god wolde ani a-mendement : þoru&yogh; is bone hire al. om. sende. To þe king he wende a-non : and axede &yogh;wat him were. "beo glad," he seide, "for of þi Quene : ne haue þou none fere!" "A, Merci, sire," quath þe king : "al mi lond ichulde orig. ichulle &yogh;yue ho-so mi&yogh;hte [it] þar-to bringue : þat þe Quene moste liue! ¶ For of þe childe ne rou&yogh;hte i nou&yogh;ht : mi&yogh;hte ich habbe hire lif." "Sire," seide þis holie Man : "lat me i-seo þi wif, &YOGH;if ich hire may to liue bringue : and þat child al-so, Þoru&yogh; mine louerdes swete grace— : nere it wel i-do?" Þis holie Man was to þe Quene i-brou&yogh;ht : þat lai &yogh;are to deþe; So clene heo was with pine ouer-come : þat vnneþe heo mi&yogh;hte breþe. ¶ Seint leonard sat a-doun a-kne : and is preiere made, Þat ore louerd hire deliueri scholde : hire freond forto glade, And þat heo moste to liue come : and al-so þat child þere, Þat Men mi&yogh;hten seo þat þe grace : of ore louerd muche were. ¶ Þe Quen a-non þoru&yogh;h is bone : deliuered was of childe, In guod lif, and hire child al-so— : þare was ore louerd wel milde! ¶ Þo þe king i-say þe Quene sauf : and þat child al-so, For ioye he nuste &yogh;wat he mi&yogh;hte : with þat holie man do; he bad he scholde of al is guod : nime &yogh;wat he wolde. Seint leonard seide, "ne kepe i nou&yogh;ht : of þi seluer ne of þi guolde, Bote a place þat ich mowe : in godes seruise inne liue." "Certes," seide þe king, "and ichulle : al þis wode þe &yogh;iue." "Ne kepe ich," quath seint leonard : "nou&yogh;ht more of þe i-bide Bote þat ich may in one ni&yogh;hte : with min Asse ouer-ride." ¶ "Ich graunti it þe," seide þe king : "ne wende þou no so wide, Þei heo were quickore þane ani best : þat is bi þis wode-side." Þis guode man a-boute þis wode wende : opo[n] is Asse wel stille And bi-rod al-so muche place : ase it was is wille. Þe king, þo it i-marked was : liet wal makie a-boute, And Aftur is wille he liet a-rere : noble hous and proute. ¶ Þare seint leonard Monk bi-cam : ase it an Abbeye were, And mani oþere he nam in to him : ore louerdes lawe to arere. he bi-gan þare a religion : of ordre swiþe strongue; Clerkus þat wolden guode men beo : to him he gan hem fongue. Nier þane a gret Mile wei : no watur nadden huy þere; Seint leonard hopede amendi þat : &yogh;if godes wille it were : he bi-gan openi þe eorþe a luyte : and is oresones he made. A swiþe fair welle þare sprong up : þat þare-inne men mi&yogh;hte wade. Þo mi&yogh;hten huy habbe watur i-nov&yogh; : þe &yogh;wile þat hous i-laste, Þoru&yogh;&yogh; godes grace and seint leonardes bone : þat heore mi&yogh;hte on the margin. þare|to casten.— ¶ "prisones louerd," seint leonard : ful wide i-cleopud was: Ore louerd him schewede fayr miracle : for some þingue it was al. & no&yogh;t for no&yogh;t it nas ! For &yogh;wane prisones criden to him : manie with dreorie chere, heore biendes borsten alle a-to : and huy deliurede were; Manie comen to þonki him : and heore feoteres with heom bere, And manie to serui ore louerd crist : bi-lefden with him þere. ¶ Seue Men with alle heore freond : þat weren of is kunne, Þo huy heorden of is guodnesse telle : huy solden lond and wunne, And wenden and woneden þare with him : holi lif to lede; Þis holie Man of godes lawe : gan heom wissi and rede. So fair Miracle ase of him was : no man nou&yogh;were nuste; Mani sik Man þare hadde bote : þat to him wel truste.— ¶ Atþe laste þo MS. þe he scholde heonne fare : longue at-fore he it wuste; his breþren he cleopede alle to him : and wel mildeliche hem custe, And wende to þe Ioye of heouene : þo god aftur him sende. Gret deol alle is breþren maden : þo he þannes wende. &YOGH;if ore louerd fair Miracle dude : on eorþe bi is liue, Aftur þat he was heonne i-wend : he dude swuche fiue. ¶ For miracle þat þare was : muche folk þudere gan falle, Þat þe place ne mi&yogh;hte nou&yogh;ht : bi manie holden alle. ¶ Þat folk cride on ore louerd &yogh;eorne : þre dai&yogh;es and þre ni&yogh;ht, Þat he scholde, &yogh;if is wille were : þar-of don insi&yogh;ht. huy i-sei&yogh;en þo þe contreie al-a-boute : i-heoled al mid snowe, And a place a-midde fair and grene : Men mi&yogh;hten þaron mowe. Þo iseien huy þat ore louerd wolde : þat þis guode man lei&yogh; e þere: huy lieten him bere þudere a-non : and a wel fair churche a-rere; Þat al þe folk þat þudere cam : ne mi&yogh;hte fulle þe place Þat ore louerd him hadde i-chose : þoru&yogh; is swete grace.— ¶ Þe scherreue of leouns : feteres made strongu[e] And in þe hexte tour of þe castel : þare he liet heom MS. heom heom hongue, So hei&yogh;e, þat ech man heom mi&yogh;hte i-seo : þat bi þe wey&yogh;e scholde wiende, And euerech man þat þar-on were : þe more him for-to schende; Þat Men þat schuuych torment isei&yogh;en : þe more scholden drede, Laste huy weren þaron i-brou&yogh;ht : to don ani mis-dede. So þat he nam ane trewe Man : for a luyte lesingue And dude him binde swiþe faste : and in þulke feoteres bringue. With pine and sorewe þis seli man was : almest i-brou&yogh;t to deþe; To seint leonard he cride &yogh;eorne : ase he mi&yogh;hte speke onneþe. ¶ Seint leonard cam a ni&yogh;ht to him : in swiþe &yogh;wite wede: "For þou hast to me &yogh;eorne i-bede : here ich am," he seide; "Þine strongue feteres bring with þe : ne haue þou none drede, And a-ris up sone a[nd] cum forth with me : for henne ichulle þe lede." vv. 115 & 116 al. transposed. ¶ Op a-ros þis selie man : with wel glade chere; his feteres borsten sone a-two : for huy bi-comen ful sere, And seint leonard ladde him forth : ase he is felawe were, To þe churche þat he inne lay : and hanguede is feteres þere. Euere ase huy bi þe weye eoden : þis holie man with him tolde, Ase þey he hadde is felawe i-beo : bi þe hond he gan him holde. Þe schirreue cam an oþur day : and is feteres sou&yogh;hte: he sai&yogh;h þat he tolde luyte of him : þat heom þudere brou&yogh;hte. al. 2 vv. more. — ¶ A luþur Man in gret power : in an oþur stude was also, Ane gultelese Man he hadde i-nome : and in strong prisone ido. he heorde telle of seint leonard : þat þe prisones help was, And þou&yogh;hte fram him is prisun wite : with som quoynte cas: he liet maken of lim and ston : a wonderliche deop put, And wit strongue dores of Ire and stiel : swyþe faste he was i-dut; On-ouewarde þe fallinde dore : þo þe guode Man was þar-inne, A strong &yogh;wuchche of Ire he liet maken : with wel quoynte ginne: Þare-inne he dude staleworþe Men : þane prison for-to wite, Þat seint leonard ne scholde nei&yogh;h him come : bote he were under&yogh;ite. Þe selie Man þat bi-neoþe was : in so strong warde i-brou&yogh;t, Criede &yogh;eorne on seint leonard : þat he ne fur-&yogh;ete him nou&yogh;ht. ¶ A ny&yogh;ht cam þis holie man : And þe &yogh;wuchche he fond þere: Sone he &yogh;weluede hire op þe doun : and heom þat þare-inne were, And sethþe he brac þe Irene dore : and ase a maister he wende a-doun, with swyþe gret ly&yogh;ht of heouene : and spac with þat prisoun: "Slepestþou?" he seide, "ich am i-come : þat þou hast i-cleopud so, Godes desciple leonard. : &yogh;wat woltþou habbe i-do?" "louerd," seide þis selie man : "al-so wis ich bidde þe Ase ich am gultles here i-do : þat þou helpe me." A-non-ri&yogh;ht þis holie Man : þe Gyues he to-brac, And bi-tweone is Armes he bar him forth : no man a-&yogh;ein him ne spac, And so hom to is owene hous : bi-twene is Armes him bar, he bad him beon a guod man : and sette him a-doun þar. ¶ Þis luþere men wit alle hore ginnes : fiebleliche habbuth a-guonne, huy mi&yogh;hten hangen up heore Ax : and leuen weork a. l. w. al. om. : for luyte huy þare wonne!— ¶ A luþer man in Alemaygne : an onkouth pilegrim nam And brou&yogh;hte him into strong prisoun : and &yogh;af him swiþe hard dom, Þat bote his freond him wolden out bugge : he scholde bi-leue þere. Þis selie Man nadde no freond : and Maude wel reulich chere, he bad for seint leonardes loue : þat he merci of him hadde; And he nolde him oþur merci do : bote into þat strong prisone him ladde. ¶ To þe louerd of þat Castel : seint leonard a-ni&yogh;ht cam And [hiet] him late gon is seriaunt : þat he with vnri&yogh;hte nam. An oþur ni&yogh;ht eft-sone he cam : and þe þridde ni&yogh;ht also, And hiet him deliuri his seriaunt. : ake neuere he nolde it do. ¶ Seint leonard ladde þis selie man : fram þe prisone a-mong heom alle; Þe hei&yogh;e tour of þat Castel a-non aftur him : a-doun gan falle And a-slov al þat folk þat þare was : bote þene louerd one; Ake boþe is leggues breken a-two : with fallingue of ane stone, Þat neuereft ne mi&yogh;hte he beon hol : noþur of flechs ne of bone; Croked he was al is lif : he nuste to &yogh;wam mene is mone.— ¶ Also in Brutayne was a kny&yogh;ht : þat in strong prisone was i-brou&yogh;ht; To seint leonard he cride faste : þat he ofte hadde i-sou&yogh;ht. Streite wardeines ouer him þare weren : boþe ny&yogh;ht and day, Þare he with strongue feteres : in prisone i-bounde lay. Seint leonard a-mong alle þe wardeins : in-to þe prisone cam Ase a maister þoru&yogh; heom alle : þisne selie kny&yogh;ht he nam, his biendes he brac formest a-two : and ladde him bi þe hond A-mong alle is wardeins : hom in-to is owene lond; ¶ his feoteres he tok him in is hond : þat he forth with him bar To seint leonardes Chapele : and a-mong oþure hieng heom þar. Þo ne dorste non of þe wardeines : a word speke with mouþe. Swuch a man may wel mayster hote : þat so heom a-gaste couþe! Þe Miracles þat he for prisones dude : ne may no man telle. Nov god for þe bone of seint leonard : us schilde fram þe pine of helle.
